**Frame-by-Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1** – Two red left‐turn arrows are clearly visible on the signal pole in the center of the intersection (one mounted above the other). There do not appear to be any other red arrow signals in view; the other red signals are circular or too far in the background to be left arrows.  
• **Frame 2** – Same two red left‐turn arrows remain in view; again, no additional arrows are apparent.  
• **Frame 3** – The two red arrows for the left turn lane are still brightly lit. No new red arrows are visible elsewhere.  
• **Frame 4** – The same pair of red left‐turn arrows is present, and there are no extra arrows lighting up.  
• **Frame 5** – Exactly the same two red left‐turn signals persist.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
Across all five frames, only these two red left‐turn arrows are ever observed. No third arrow—or additional red arrow—comes into view, despite the presence of other red lights (which appear to be solid red signals for different lanes or farther intersections).  

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• A. 0 – Not possible, as two clearly lit red left‐turn arrows are seen.  
• B. 1 – Incorrect; there are consistently two red left‐turn arrows.  
• C. 2 – Matches our observation (two distinct red left‐turn arrows remain lit throughout).  
• D. 3 – No evidence of a third red arrow in any frame.  

**Provide the Best Answer**  
<answer>C</answer>
